M.G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 28.proposition: A Probate and Family Court may modify an existing judgment regarding custody and parenting time “as the circumstances of the parents and the benefit of the children may require.” M.G.L. c. 208, § 28.

M.G.L. c. 209C, \u00a7 20.proposition: COMPLAINT FOR MODIFICATION (M.G.L. c. 208, § 28; M.G.L. c. 209C, § 20; M.G.L. c. 208, § 31 et seq.)

M.G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 31 et seq..proposition: COMPLAINT FOR MODIFICATION (M.G.L. c. 208, § 28; M.G.L. c. 209C, § 20; M.G.L. c. 208, § 31 et seq.)

M.G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 31.proposition: This Court has subject matter jurisdiction over this action pursuant to M.G.L. c. 208, § 28, and M.G.L. c. 208, § 31, because this is a post-judgment custody matter involving a prior judgment of this Court, and the child and both parents reside in the Commonwealth of Massachusetts.

M.G.L. c. 215, \u00a7 3.proposition: Venue is proper in the Norfolk Division of the Probate and Family Court Department pursuant to M.G.L. c. 215, § 3, and applicable rules because the prior custody judgment was entered in this Court and the parties and child reside in this county.

M.G.L. c. 215, \u00a7 6.proposition: The Court has broad equitable authority under M.G.L. c. 215, § 6, and M.G.L. c. 208, § 28, to fashion a parenting plan that protects the child’s best interests, including adjusting a 50/50 schedule to a primary‑residence arrangement while preserving appropriate parenting time with the other parent.

Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177, 184\u20.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, modification of custody requires (1) a material and substantial change in circumstances since the entry of the prior judgment, and (2) that modification is in the best interests of the child.
Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177, 184\u20.support_reasoning: This opinion is a removal/relocation case under G.L. c. 208, § 30, focused on the ‘cause shown’/best interests standard where parents share joint custody. It does not state or apply the general Massachusetts standard for modification of custody as requiring both (1) a material and substantial change in circumstances and (2) best interests of the child. The only ‘change in circumstances’ language appears in a quoted ALI provision in a footnote, not as a statement of Massachusetts modification law, so the case does not support the specific proposition cited.
Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177, 184\u20.relevant_excerpt:
The Principles of the Law of Family Dissolution § 2.17 (2002), as adopted and promulgated by the American Law Institute, state in pertinent part:
“(1) The relocation of a parent constitutes a substantial change in circumstances . . . only when the relocation significantly impairs either parent’s ability to exercise responsibilities the parent has been exercising or attempting to exercise [under the judgement of divorce]...
“(4) When a relocation constituting changed circumstances . . . renders it impractical to maintain the same proportion of custodial responsibility to each parent, the court should modify the parenting plan in accordance with the child’s best interests ...”

Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, modification of custody requires (1) a material and substantial change in circumstances since the entry of the prior judgment, and (2) that modification is in the best interests of the child.
Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.support_reasoning: The opinion in Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas deals with an initial divorce judgment awarding custody and addressing removal of children from the Commonwealth, not with a post-judgment *modification* of custody. The court discusses standards for removal under G.L. c. 208, § 30, and the best interests analysis, but it does not articulate or apply the two-part standard requiring a material and substantial change in circumstances since a prior custody judgment. Thus, it is not authority for the specific Massachusetts modification standard described in the proposition.
Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.relevant_excerpt: “The Massachusetts removal statute, G. L. c. 208, § 30 (1984 ed.), provides that ‘[a] minor child of divorced parents who is a native of . . . this commonwealth . . . shall not, if of suitable age to signify his consent, be removed out of this commonwealth without such consent, or, if under that age, without the consent of both parents, unless the court upon cause shown otherwise orders.’ The words ‘upon cause shown’ mean only that removal must be in the best interests of the child (Rubin v. Rubin, 370 Mass. 857 [1976]; Hale v. Hale, supra at 815)…”}

Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834, 842\u201.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, modification of custody requires (1) a material and substantial change in circumstances since the entry of the prior judgment, and (2) that modification is in the best interests of the child.
Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834, 842\u201.support_reasoning: This opinion distinguishes between an initial custody determination under G. L. c. 209C, § 10(a), which uses a pure ‘best interests of the child’ standard, and a later modification proceeding under § 20, which requires a ‘substantial change in circumstances.’ The court expressly declines to apply the modification standard here because the case was tried as an original custody proceeding, not as a modification, and does not articulate the two-part ‘material and substantial change plus best interests’ test for modifications. Thus, it does not support the claimed general proposition about modification of custody under Massachusetts law.
Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834, 842\u201.relevant_excerpt: “We also decline to consider the father’s claim that the probate judge should have applied the ‘substantial change in the circumstances’ standard applicable to modification actions brought under G. L. c. 209C, § 20, rather than the ‘best interests of the child’ standard applicable to custody determinations under G. L. c. 209C, § 10 (a). … It is clear from the record that the case in the Probate Court was tried under G. L. c. 209C, § 10 (a), not G. L. c. 209C, § 20….”}

Wilkins v. Wilkins, 86 Mass. App. Ct. 66.raw_text: Wilkins v. Wilkins, 86 Mass. App. Ct. 665, 669 (2014)
Wilkins v. Wilkins, 86 Mass. App. Ct. 66.proposition: The “best interests of the child” is the paramount consideration in any custody determination.
Wilkins v. Wilkins, 86 Mass. App. Ct. 66.support_reasoning: The provided opinion is a Massachusetts Appeals Court decision about defamation, conditional privilege, summary judgment, and a c. 93A claim arising from a roofing dispute. It does not involve custody or family law, nor does it mention or analyze the “best interests of the child” standard. Therefore, it cannot be cited as authority for the proposition that the best interests of the child is the paramount consideration in custody determinations.
Wilkins v. Wilkins, 86 Mass. App. Ct. 66.relevant_excerpt: In order for Chutehall to recover on its defamation claim, it must establish that (1) Follett published a defamatory statement of and concerning Chutehall; (2) the statement was a false statement of fact (as opposed to opinion); (3) Follett was at fault for making the statement and any privilege that may have attached to the statement was abused; and (4) Chutehall suffered damages as a result, or the statement was of the type that is actionable without proof of economic loss.

Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398, 4.raw_text: Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398, 404 (1981)
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398, 4.proposition: The “best interests of the child” is the paramount consideration in any custody determination.
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398, 4.support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly states that in deciding custody issues the court’s overriding concern must be the promotion of the children’s best interests and welfare, and it relies on that standard to affirm the custody award. The court describes this as the controlling or sole question in custody determinations, which aligns directly with the proposition that the child’s best interests are paramount in custody decisions.
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398, 4.relevant_excerpt: “However, in deciding issues involving custody, the overriding concern of the court must be the promotion of the best interests of the children and their general welfare. … [I]n determining the question of custody… ‘the happiness and the welfare of the children] should be the controlling consideration. It is the duty of the judge to consider the welfare of the children] in reference not merely to the present, but also to the probable future….’”

Custody of a Minor, 383 Mass. 595, 599\u.proposition: In determining the best interests of the child, the Court must consider, among other factors, the child’s safety, stability, and well‑being, the capacity of each parent to provide for the child’s needs, and any circumstance that may create risk of physical or emotional harm.
Custody of a Minor, 383 Mass. 595, 599\u.support_reasoning: The opinion focuses on the constitutional and statutory requirement of parental unfitness and the risk of serious harm as conditions for state intervention, and on the weight to be given to the child’s wishes. While it discusses psychological harm and the child’s development, it does not articulate a general best‑interests test requiring consideration of safety, stability, well‑being, and each parent’s capacity in the way the proposition states. The case is about adjudicating a child in need of care and protection and justifying removal from a parent, not setting out a multi‑factor best‑interests framework as claimed.
Custody of a Minor, 383 Mass. 595, 599\u.relevant_excerpt: “A finding of parental unfitness may be predicated on the circumstances within a particular family, as they adversely affect the particular child, without regard to the general quality of parental conduct per se. ‘It is not the quality or character of parental conduct per se that justifies State intervention on behalf of an abused, neglected, or otherwise endangered child. Rather, it is the fact of the endangerment itself. As parens patriae the State does not act to punish misbehaving parents; rather it acts to protect endangered children.’ … The State may constitutionally deprive otherwise fit parents of custody of their minor child upon a persuasive showing that return of that custody to the parents would create a substantial risk or likelihood of serious harm to the child.”

Dodge v. Dodge, 18 Mass. App. Ct. 292, 2.raw_text: Dodge v. Dodge, 18 Mass. App. Ct. 292, 297–98 (1984)
Dodge v. Dodge, 18 Mass. App. Ct. 292, 2.proposition: In determining the best interests of the child, the Court must consider, among other factors, the child’s safety, stability, and well‑being, the capacity of each parent to provide for the child’s needs, and any circumstance that may create risk of physical or emotional harm.
Dodge v. Dodge, 18 Mass. App. Ct. 292, 2.support_reasoning: The opinion is a criminal case about armed robbery, jury instructions, admissibility of escape evidence, and prosecutorial argument; it does not involve child custody, best interests of the child, or any family-law standards. Nowhere does the court discuss factors such as child safety, stability, parental capacity, or risk of harm in a custody or best‑interests analysis. Therefore, this case does not support the cited proposition regarding best interests of the child.
Dodge v. Dodge, 18 Mass. App. Ct. 292, 2.relevant_excerpt: We find no compelling analogy between this case and the Corcione decision. The error in Corcione arose from instructions which confronted a jury considering several indictments with “an all or nothing” situation by telling them that the case would permit only one of two results: either not guilty on all indictments, or guilty on all indictments (364 Mass, at 617-618). There was no similar instruction given here.

Care & Protection of Three Minors, 392 M.raw_text: Care & Protection of Three Minors, 392 Mass. 704, 712–13 (1984)
Care & Protection of Three Minors, 392 M.proposition: A parent’s significant change in physical or mental health can constitute a material and substantial change in circumstances warranting review and modification of a prior custody order, where it affects the parent’s ability to care safely for the child.
Care & Protection of Three Minors, 392 M.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns initial care-and-protection and permanent custody determinations, focusing on current parental unfitness and best interests, not on modification of a prior custody order based on a material change in circumstances. Although the facts mention the mother’s health problems, the court does not analyze a “significant change” in her physical or mental health as a basis to reopen or modify an existing custody judgment. There is no discussion of the legal standard for modification of prior custody orders or material and substantial change in circumstances; thus the case does not support the stated proposition.
Care & Protection of Three Minors, 392 M.relevant_excerpt: “The removal of a child from the custody of his or her parent may be ordered only if there is clear and convincing evidence that the parent is currently unfit to care for that child… The judge’s findings are adequate under this standard to support the removal of the children from the mother’s care… We agree with the trial judge that there is clear and convincing evidence that the mother has ‘grievous shortcomings or handicaps that would put the child’s welfare in the family milieu much at hazard’ and that she is currently unfit to care for her three children.”

Adoption of Ilona, 459 Mass. 53, 61\u201.proposition: A parent’s significant change in physical or mental health can constitute a material and substantial change in circumstances warranting review and modification of a prior custody order, where it affects the parent’s ability to care safely for the child.
Adoption of Ilona, 459 Mass. 53, 61\u201.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns termination of parental rights in a care and protection/adoption proceeding, not modification of a prior custody order. While the court discusses parental unfitness, cognitive limitations, and the likelihood that unfitness will be temporary or permanent, it does not frame these issues as a ‘material and substantial change in circumstances’ standard or as grounds to reopen or modify an existing custody judgment. Thus, it does not establish the specific proposition that a significant change in a parent’s physical or mental health constitutes such a change warranting review of a prior custody order.
Adoption of Ilona, 459 Mass. 53, 61\u201.relevant_excerpt: “Because termination of a parent’s rights is an ‘extreme step,’ … a judge must decide both whether the parent is currently unfit and whether, ‘on the basis of credible evidence, there is a reasonable likelihood that the parent’s unfitness at the time of trial may be only temporary.’… However, a judge’s conclusion that a parent’s unfitness is temporary must rest on credible evidence supporting a reasonable likelihood that the parent will become fit, not on a ‘faint hope.’”

R.H. v. B.F., 39 Mass. App. Ct. 29, 42\u.proposition: The Court has broad equitable authority under M.G.L. c. 215, § 6, and M.G.L. c. 208, § 28, to fashion a parenting plan that protects the child’s best interests, including adjusting a 50/50 schedule to a primary‑residence arrangement while preserving appropriate parenting time with the other parent.
R.H. v. B.F., 39 Mass. App. Ct. 29, 42\u.support_reasoning: The opinion focuses on standards for custody determinations under G.L. c. 209C and the need for detailed findings regarding domestic violence, not on the scope of the Probate and Family Court’s equitable authority under G.L. c. 215, § 6 or c. 208, § 28. It does not discuss those statutes, equitable power to fashion parenting plans, or shifting from a 50/50 schedule to a primary‑residence arrangement while preserving parenting time. The case instead reverses a custody judgment due to inadequate findings and provides guidance on considering domestic violence in best‑interests analysis, so it does not support the specific proposition claimed.
R.H. v. B.F., 39 Mass. App. Ct. 29, 42\u.relevant_excerpt: “Neither G. L. c. 209C, § 10(c)… nor G. L. c. 208, § 31… specify or enumerate factors which must or should be considered in determining custody… Instead, custody orders and judgments are made on the basis of a determination of the best interests of the child, and the statutes leave it to the trial judge to identify and weigh any factors found pertinent to those interests in the circumstances of the specific dispute.”

Vilakazi v. Maxie, 371 Mass. 406, 409\u2.proposition: The Court has broad equitable authority under M.G.L. c. 215, § 6, and M.G.L. c. 208, § 28, to fashion a parenting plan that protects the child’s best interests, including adjusting a 50/50 schedule to a primary‑residence arrangement while preserving appropriate parenting time with the other parent.
Vilakazi v. Maxie, 371 Mass. 406, 409\u2.support_reasoning: The opinion does affirm that the controlling principle in custody matters is the welfare of the child and that the probate judge has broad discretion in custody decisions, referencing G.L. c. 208, § 28 for future modification. However, it does not discuss G.L. c. 215, § 6, does not frame the authority as ‘broad equitable’ power under those statutes, and does not address adjusting a 50/50 schedule to a primary‑residence arrangement while preserving parenting time. Instead, it upholds an order granting sole custody to the father and stepmother with no visitation for the mother, which is materially different from the specific proposition claimed.
Vilakazi v. Maxie, 371 Mass. 406, 409\u2.relevant_excerpt: “The governing principle by which the court must be guided in deciding the issues raised is the welfare of the child… In providing for the custody of a minor child… the happiness and the welfare of the child should be the controlling consideration. It is the duty of the judge to consider the welfare of the child in reference not merely to the present, but also to the probable future, and it is a subject peculiarly within the discretion of the judge.… As to the circumstances in which orders for the custody of minor children may be subject to future modification by the court see G. L. c. 208, §§ 28 and 30…”}
